<br>heritage of  Jacob thy father: for the mouth of  the L</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:6px">ORD</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px"> hath spoken it.  </span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT-Bold; font-size:9px">Luke 4:16.
<br></span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px">And he came to Nazareth, where he had been brought up: and, as his custom was, he
<br>went into the synagogue on the sabbath day, and stood up for to read.  </span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT-Bold; font-size:9px">Matt. 12:1–
<br>13.</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px"> At that time Jesus went on the sabbath day through the corn; and his disciples
<br>were an hungred, and began to pluck the ears of  corn, and to eat. But when the
<br>Pharisees saw it, they said unto him, Behold, thy disciples do that which is not lawful to
<br>do upon the sabbath day. But he said unto them, Have ye not read what David did,
<br>when he was an hungred, and they that were with him; how he entered into the house
<br>of  God, and did eat the shewbread, which was not lawful for him to eat, neither for
<br>them which were with him, but only for the priests? Or have ye not read in the law,
<br>how that on the sabbath days the priests in the temple profane the sabbath, and are
<br>blameless? But I say unto you, That in this place is one greater than the temple. But if
<br>ye had known what this meaneth, I will have mercy, and not sacrifice, ye would not
<br>have condemned the guiltless. For the Son of  man is Lord even of  the sabbath day.
<br>And when he was departed thence, he went into their synagogue: and, behold, there
<br>was a man which had his hand withered. And they asked him, saying, Is it lawful to
<br>heal on the sabbath days? that they might accuse him. And he said unto them, What
<br>man shall there be among you, that shall have one sheep, and if  it fall into a pit on the
<br>sabbath day, will he not lay hold on it, and lift it out? How much then is a man better
<br>than a sheep? Wherefore it is lawful to do well on the sabbath days. Then saith he to
<br>the man, Stretch forth thine hand. And he stretched it forth; and it was restored whole,
<br>like as the other.  </span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT-Bold; font-size:9px">Mark 3:1–5.</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px"> And he entered again into the synagogue; and there
<br></span></div><span style="position:absolute; border: gray 1px solid; left:0px; top:62970px; width:342px; height:522px;"></span>
<div style="position:absolute; top:62970px;"><a name="111">Page 111</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; border: textbox 1px solid; writing-mode:lr-tb; left:36px; top:62996px; width:48px; height:9px;"><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px">CHAPTER 22
<br></span></div><div style="position:absolute; border: textbox 1px solid; writing-mode:lr-tb; left:116px; top:62996px; width:109px; height:9px;"><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px">THE CONFESSION OF FAITH
<br></span></div><div style="position:absolute; border: textbox 1px solid; writing-mode:lr-tb; left:294px; top:62996px; width:12px; height:9px;"><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px">111
<br></span></div><div style="position:absolute; border: textbox 1px solid; writing-mode:lr-tb; left:139px; top:63014px; width:63px; height:13px;"><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT-Bold; font-size:13px">Chapter 22
<br></span></div><div style="position:absolute; border: textbox 1px solid; writing-mode:lr-tb; left:94px; top:63029px; width:152px; height:13px;"><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT-Bold; font-size:13px">Of  Lawful Oaths and Vows
<br></span></div><div style="position:absolute; border: textbox 1px solid; writing-mode:lr-tb; left:36px; top:63054px; width:270px; height:46px;"><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:11px">1.  A lawful oath is a part of  religious worship,</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:8px">a</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:11px"> wherein, upon
<br>just occasion, the person swearing solemnly calleth God to witness
<br>what he asserteth, or promiseth, and to judge him according to the
<br>truth or falsehood of  what he sweareth.</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:8px">b
<br></span></div><div style="position:absolute; border: textbox 1px solid; writing-mode:lr-tb; left:36px; top:63101px; width:270px; height:34px;"><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:11px">2.  The name of  God only is that by which men ought to swear,
<br>and therein it is to be used with all holy fear and reverence.</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:8px">c </span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:11px">There-
<br>fore, to swear vainly, or rashly, by that glorious and dreadful Name;
<br></span></div><div style="position:absolute; border: textbox 1px solid; writing-mode:lr-tb; left:36px; top:63154px; width:270px; height:64px;"><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px">was a man there which had a withered hand. And they watched him, whether he
<br>would heal him on the sabbath day; that they might accuse him. And he saith unto the
<br>man which had the withered hand, Stand forth. And he saith unto them, Is it lawful to
<br>do good on the sabbath days, or to do evil? to save life, or to kill? But they held their
<br>peace. And when he had looked round about on them with anger, being grieved for
<br>the hardness of  their hearts, he saith unto the man, Stretch forth thine hand. And he
<br>stretched it out: and his hand was restored whole as the other.
<br></span></div><div style="position:absolute; border: textbox 1px solid; writing-mode:lr-tb; left:35px; top:63227px; width:270px; height:73px;"><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px">a.  </span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT-Bold; font-size:9px">Deut. 10:20.</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px"> Thou shalt fear the L</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:6px">ORD</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px"> thy God; him shalt thou serve, and to
<br></span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px">him shalt thou cleave, and swear by his name.  </span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT-Bold; font-size:9px">Isa. 45:23.</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px"> I have sworn by myself, the
<br>word is gone out of  my mouth in righteousness, and shall not return, That unto me
<br>every knee shall bow, every tongue shall swear.  </span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT-Bold; font-size:9px">Rom. 14:11.</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px"> For it is written, As I
<br>live, saith the Lord, every knee shall bow to me, and every tongue shall confess to God.
<br></span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT-Bold; font-size:9px">Phil. 2:10–11.</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px"> That at the name of  Jesus every knee should bow, of  things in heaven,
<br>and things in earth, and things under the earth; and that every tongue should confess
<br>that Jesus Christ is Lord, to the glory of  God the Father.
<br></span></div><div style="position:absolute; border: textbox 1px solid; writing-mode:lr-tb; left:36px; top:63301px; width:270px; height:119px;"><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px">b.  </span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT-Bold; font-size:9px">Ex. 20:7.</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px"> Thou shalt not take the name of  the L</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:6px">ORD</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px"> thy God in vain; for the
<br>L</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:6px">ORD</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px"> will not hold him guiltless that taketh his name in vain.  </span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT-Bold; font-size:9px">Lev. 19:12.</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px"> And ye
<br>shall not swear by my name falsely, neither shalt thou profane the name of  thy God: I
<br>am the L</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:6px">ORD</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px">.  </span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT-Bold; font-size:9px">Rom. 1:9.</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px"> For God is my witness, whom I serve with my spirit in the
<br>gospel of  his Son, that without ceasing I make mention of  you always in my prayers.
<br></span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT-Bold; font-size:9px">2 Cor. 1:23.</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px"> Moreover I call God for a record upon my soul, that to spare you I came
<br>not as yet unto Corinth.  </span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT-Bold; font-size:9px">2 Cor. 11:31.</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px"> The God and Father of  our Lord Jesus Christ,
<br>which is blessed for evermore, knoweth that I lie not.  </span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT-Bold; font-size:9px">Gal. 1:20.</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px"> Now the things
<br>which I write unto you, behold, before God, I lie not.  </span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT-Bold; font-size:9px">2 Chron. 6:22–23.</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px"> If  a man
<br>sin against his neighbour, and an oath be laid upon him to make him swear, and the
<br>oath come before thine altar in this house; then hear thou from heaven, and do, and
<br>judge thy servants, by requiting the wicked, by recompensing his way upon his own
<br>head; and by justifying the righteous, by giving him according to his righteousness.
<br></span></div><div style="position:absolute; border: textbox 1px solid; writing-mode:lr-tb; left:36px; top:63420px; width:269px; height:36px;"><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px">c.  </span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT-Bold; font-size:9px">Deut. 6:13.</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px"> Thou shalt fear the L</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:6px">ORD</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px"> thy God, and serve him, and shalt
<br>swear by his name.  </span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT-Bold; font-size:9px">Josh. 23:7.</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px"> … that ye come not among these nations, these that
<br>remain among you; neither make mention of  the name of  their gods, nor cause to
<br>swear by them, neither serve them, nor bow yourselves unto them.
<br></span></div><span style="position:absolute; border: gray 1px solid; left:0px; top:63542px; width:342px; height:522px;"></span>
<div style="position:absolute; top:63542px;"><a name="112">Page 112</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; border: textbox 1px solid; writing-mode:lr-tb; left:36px; top:63568px; width:12px; height:9px;"><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px">112
<br></span></div><div style="position:absolute; border: textbox 1px solid; writing-mode:lr-tb; left:116px; top:63568px; width:109px; height:9px;"><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px">THE CONFESSION OF FAITH
<br></span></div><div style="position:absolute; border: textbox 1px solid; writing-mode:lr-tb; left:257px; top:63568px; width:48px; height:9px;"><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px">CHAPTER 22
<br></span></div><div style="position:absolute; border: textbox 1px solid; writing-mode:lr-tb; left:36px; top:63585px; width:270px; height:57px;"><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:11px">or, to swear at all by any other thing, is sinful, and to be abhorred.</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:8px">d
<br></span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:11px">Yet, as in matters of  weight and moment, an oath is warranted by the
<br>Word of  God, under the new testament as well as under the old;</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:8px">e </span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:11px">so
<br>a lawful oath, being imposed by lawful authority, in such matters,
<br>ought to be taken.</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:8px">f
<br></span></div><div style="position:absolute; border: textbox 1px solid; writing-mode:lr-tb; left:36px; top:63643px; width:270px; height:57px;"><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:11px">3.  Whosoever taketh an oath ought duly to consider the weighti-
<br>ness of  so solemn an act, and therein to avouch nothing but what he
<br>is fully persuaded is the truth:</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:8px">g </span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:11px">neither may any man bind himself  by
<br>oath to anything but what is good and just, and what he believeth so
<br>to be, and what he is able and resolved to perform.</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:8px">h
<br></span></div><div style="position:absolute; border: textbox 1px solid; writing-mode:lr-tb; left:35px; top:63708px; width:270px; height:128px;"><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px">d.  </span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT-Bold; font-size:9px">Ex. 20:7.</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px"> Thou shalt not take the name of  the L</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:6px">ORD</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px"> thy God in vain; for the
<br>L</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:6px">ORD</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px"> will not hold him guiltless that taketh his name in vain.  </span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT-Bold; font-size:9px">Jer. 5:7.</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px"> How shall I
<br>pardon thee for this? thy children have forsaken me, and sworn by them that are no
<br>gods: when I had fed them to the full, they then committed adultery, and assembled
<br>themselves by troops in the harlots’ houses.  </span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT-Bold; font-size:9px">Matt. 5:33–37.</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px"> Again, ye have heard
<br>that it hath been said by them of  old time, Thou shalt not forswear thyself, but shalt
<br>perform unto the Lord thine oaths: but I say unto you, Swear not at all; neither by
<br>heaven; for it is God’s throne: nor by the earth; for it is his footstool: neither by Jerusa-
<br>lem; for it is the city of  the great King. Neither shalt thou swear by thy head, because
<br>thou canst not make one hair white or black. But let your communication be, Yea,
<br>yea; Nay, nay: for whatsoever is more than these cometh of  evil.  </span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT-Bold; font-size:9px">James 5:12.</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px"> But
<br></span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px">above  all  things,  my  brethren,  swear  not,  neither  by  heaven,  neither  by  the  earth,
<br>neither by any other oath: but let your yea be yea; and your nay, nay; lest ye fall into
<br>condemnation.
<br></span></div><div style="position:absolute; border: textbox 1px solid; writing-mode:lr-tb; left:35px; top:63837px; width:270px; height:55px;"><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px">e.  </span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT-Bold; font-size:9px">Heb. 6:16.</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px"> For men verily swear by the greater: and an oath for confirmation
<br>is to them an end of  all strife.  </span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT-Bold; font-size:9px">2 Cor. 1:23.</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px"> Moreover I call God for a record upon my
<br>soul, that to spare you I came not as yet unto Corinth.  </span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT-Bold; font-size:9px">Isa. 65:16.</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px"> … that he who
<br>blesseth himself  in the earth shall bless himself  in the God of  truth; and he that sweareth
<br>in the earth shall swear by the God of  truth; because the former troubles are forgotten,
<br>and because they are hid from mine eyes.
<br></span></div><div style="position:absolute; border: textbox 1px solid; writing-mode:lr-tb; left:35px; top:63892px; width:270px; height:64px;"><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px">f.  </span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT-Bold; font-size:9px">1 Kings 8:31.</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px"> If  any man trespass against his neighbour, and an oath be laid
<br>upon him to cause him to swear, and the oath come before thine altar in this house …
<br></span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT-Bold; font-size:9px">Neh. 13:25.</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px"> And I contended with them, and cursed them, and smote certain of
<br>them, and plucked off  their hair, and made them swear by God, saying, Ye shall not
<br>give your daughters unto their sons, nor take their daughters unto your sons, or for
<br>yourselves.  </span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT-Bold; font-size:9px">Ezra 10:5.</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px"> Then arose Ezra, and made the chief  priests, the Levites, and
<br>all Israel, to swear that they should do according to this word. And they sware.
<br></span></div><div style="position:absolute; border: textbox 1px solid; writing-mode:lr-tb; left:36px; top:63956px; width:270px; height:64px;"><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px">g.  </span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT-Bold; font-size:9px">Ex. 20:7.</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px"> Thou shalt not take the name of  the L</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:6px">ORD</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px"> thy God in vain; for the
<br>L</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:6px">ORD</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px"> will not hold him guiltless that taketh his name in vain.  </span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT-Bold; font-size:9px">Lev. 19:12.</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px"> And ye
<br>shall not swear by my name falsely, neither shalt thou profane the name of  thy God: I
<br>am the L</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:6px">ORD</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px">.  </span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT-Bold; font-size:9px">Jer. 4:2.</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px"> And thou shalt swear, The L</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:6px">ORD</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px"> liveth, in truth, in judgment,
<br></span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px">and in righteousness; and the nations shall bless themselves in him, and in him shall
<br></span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px">they glory.  </span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT-Bold; font-size:9px">Hos. 10:4.</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px"> They have spoken words, swearing falsely in making a cov-
<br>enant: thus judgment springeth up as hemlock in the furrows of  the field.
<br></span></div><div style="position:absolute; border: textbox 1px solid; writing-mode:lr-tb; left:49px; top:64021px; width:256px; height:9px;"><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px">h.  </span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT-Bold; font-size:9px">Gen. 24:2–9.</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px"> And Abraham said unto his eldest servant of  his house, that
<br></span></div><span style="position:absolute; border: gray 1px solid; left:0px; top:64114px; width:342px; height:522px;"></span>
<div style="position:absolute; top:64114px;"><a name="113">Page 113</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; border: textbox 1px solid; writing-mode:lr-tb; left:36px; top:64140px; width:48px; height:9px;"><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px">CHAPTER 22
<br></span></div><div style="position:absolute; border: textbox 1px solid; writing-mode:lr-tb; left:116px; top:64140px; width:109px; height:9px;"><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px">THE CONFESSION OF FAITH
<br></span></div><div style="position:absolute; border: textbox 1px solid; writing-mode:lr-tb; left:294px; top:64140px; width:12px; height:9px;"><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px">113
<br></span></div><div style="position:absolute; border: textbox 1px solid; writing-mode:lr-tb; left:35px; top:64157px; width:270px; height:57px;"><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:11px">4.  An oath is to be taken in the plain and common sense of  the
<br>words, without equivocation, or mental reservation.</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:8px">i </span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:11px">It cannot oblige
<br>to sin; but in anything not sinful, being taken, it binds to performance,
<br>although to a man’s own hurt.</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:8px">k </span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:11px">Nor is it to be violated, although made
<br>to heretics, or infidels.</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:8px">l
<br></span></div><div style="position:absolute; border: textbox 1px solid; writing-mode:lr-tb; left:36px; top:64233px; width:270px; height:128px;"><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px">ruled over all that he had, Put, I pray thee, thy hand under my thigh: and I will make
<br>thee swear by the L</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:6px">ORD</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px">, the God of  heaven, and the God of  the earth, that thou shalt
<br>not  take  a  wife  unto  my  son  of   the  daughters  of   the  Canaanites,  among  whom  I
<br>dwell.… And the servant put his hand under the thigh of  Abraham his master, and
<br>sware to him concerning that matter.  </span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT-Bold; font-size:9px">Neh. 5:12–13.</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px"> Then said they, We will restore
<br>them, and will require nothing of  them; so will we do as thou sayest. Then I called the
<br>priests, and took an oath of  them, that they should do according to this promise. Also
<br>I shook my lap, and said, So God shake out every man from his house, and from his
<br>labour, that performeth not this promise, even thus be he shaken out, and emptied.
<br>And all the congregation said, Amen, and praised the L</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:6px">ORD</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px">. And the people did ac-
<br>cording to this promise.  </span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT-Bold; font-size:9px">Eccl. 5:2,  5.</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px"> Be not rash with thy mouth, and let not thine
<br>heart be hasty to utter any thing before God: for God is in heaven, and thou upon
<br>earth: therefore let thy words be few.… Better is it that thou shouldest not vow, than
<br>that thou shouldest vow and not pay.

<br></span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px">as thou very well knowest. For if  I be an offender, or have committed any thing worthy

<br>bought them, and bring upon themselves swift destruction.… But chiefly them that
<br>walk after the flesh in the lust of  uncleanness, and despise government. Presumptuous
<br>are they, selfwilled, they are not afraid to speak evil of  dignities. Whereas angels, which
<br>are greater in power and might, bring not railing accusation against them before the
<br>Lord.  </span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT-Bold; font-size:9px">Jude 8–11.</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px"> Likewise also these filthy dreamers defile the flesh, despise domin-

<br>devil he disputed about the body of  Moses, durst not bring against him a railing accu-
<br>sation, but said, The Lord rebuke thee. But these speak evil of  those things which they
<br>know not: but what they know naturally, as brute beasts, in those things they corrupt
<br>themselves. Woe unto them! for they have gone in the way of  Cain, and ran greedily
<br>after the error of  Balaam for reward, and perished in the gainsaying of  Core.

<br>baptism doth also now save us (not the putting away of  the filth of  the flesh, but the
<br>answer of  a good conscience toward God,) by the resurrection of  Jesus Christ.  </span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT-Bold; font-size:9px">Acts
<br>2:38,  41.</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px"> Then Peter said unto them, Repent, and be baptized every one of  you in
<br></span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px">the name of  Jesus Christ for the remission of  sins, and ye shall receive the gift of  the
<br>Holy Ghost.… Then they that gladly received his word were baptized: and the same
<br>day there were added unto them about three thousand souls.
<br></span></div><div style="position:absolute; border: textbox 1px solid; writing-mode:lr-tb; left:35px; top:78265px; width:270px; height:64px;"><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px">s.  </span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT-Bold; font-size:9px">Rom. 6:3–11.</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px"> Know ye not, that so many of  us as were baptized into Jesus
<br>Christ were baptized into his death? Therefore we are buried with him by baptism
<br>into death: that like as Christ was raised up from the dead by the glory of  the Father,
<br></span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px">even so we also should walk in newness of  life. For if  we have been planted together in
<br></span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px">the likeness of  his death, we shall be also in the likeness of  his resurrection: knowing
<br>this, that our old man is crucified with him, that the body of  sin might be destroyed,
<br>that henceforth we should not serve sin. For he that is dead is freed from sin. Now if  we

<div style="position:absolute; border: textbox 1px solid; writing-mode:lr-tb; left:36px; top:78440px; width:12px; height:9px;"><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px">138

<br></span></div><div style="position:absolute; border: textbox 1px solid; writing-mode:lr-tb; left:257px; top:78440px; width:48px; height:9px;"><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px">CHAPTER 29
<br></span></div><div style="position:absolute; border: textbox 1px solid; writing-mode:lr-tb; left:139px; top:78458px; width:63px; height:13px;"><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT-Bold; font-size:13px">Chapter 29
<br></span></div><div style="position:absolute; border: textbox 1px solid; writing-mode:lr-tb; left:110px; top:78473px; width:120px; height:13px;"><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT-Bold; font-size:13px">Of  the Lord’s Supper
<br></span></div><div style="position:absolute; border: textbox 1px solid; writing-mode:lr-tb; left:36px; top:78499px; width:270px; height:103px;"><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:11px">1.  Our Lord Jesus, in the night wherein he was betrayed, insti-
<br>tuted the sacrament of  his body and blood, called the Lord’s Supper,
<br>to be observed in his church, unto the end of  the world, for the per-
<br>petual remembrance of  the sacrifice of  himself  in his death; the seal-
<br>ing all benefits thereof  unto true believers, their spiritual nourish-
<br>ment and growth in him, their further engagement in and to all du-
<br>ties which they owe unto him; and, to be a bond and pledge of  their
<br>communion with him, and with each other, as members of  his mys-
<br>tical body.</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:8px">a
<br></span></div><div style="position:absolute; border: textbox 1px solid; writing-mode:lr-tb; left:36px; top:78602px; width:270px; height:34px;"><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:11px">2.  In this sacrament, Christ is not offered up to his Father; nor
<br>any real sacrifice made at all, for remission of  sins of  the quick or
<br>dead;</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:8px">b</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:11px"> but only a commemoration of  that one offering up of  himself,
<br></span></div><div style="position:absolute; border: textbox 1px solid; writing-mode:lr-tb; left:36px; top:78644px; width:270px; height:46px;"><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px">be dead with Christ, we believe that we shall also live with him: knowing that Christ
<br>being raised from the dead dieth no more; death hath no more dominion over him.
<br>For in that he died, he died unto sin once: but in that he liveth, he liveth unto God.
<br>Likewise reckon ye also yourselves to be dead indeed unto sin, but alive unto God
<br></span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px">through Jesus Christ our Lord.
<br></span></div><div style="position:absolute; border: textbox 1px solid; writing-mode:lr-tb; left:36px; top:78699px; width:270px; height:128px;"><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px">a.  </span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT-Bold; font-size:9px">1 Cor. 11:23–26.</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px"> For I have received of  the Lord that which also I delivered
<br>unto you, That the Lord Jesus the same night in which he was betrayed took bread:
<br>and when he had given thanks, he brake it, and said, Take, eat: this is my body, which
<br>is broken for you: this do in remembrance of  me. After the same manner also he took
<br>the cup, when he had supped, saying, This cup is the new testament in my blood: this
<br>do ye, as oft as ye drink it, in remembrance of  me. For as often as ye eat this bread, and
<br>drink this cup, ye do shew the Lord’s death till he come.  </span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT-Bold; font-size:9px">1 Cor. 10:16–17,  21.</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px"> The
<br>cup of  blessing which we bless, is it not the communion of  the blood of  Christ? The
<br>bread which we break, is it not the communion of  the body of  Christ? For we being
<br>many are one bread, and one body: for we are all partakers of  that one bread.… Ye
<br>cannot drink the cup of  the Lord, and the cup of  devils: ye cannot be partakers of  the
<br></span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px">Lord’s table, and of  the table of  devils.  </span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT-Bold; font-size:9px">1 Cor. 12:13.</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px"> For by one Spirit are we all
<br></span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px">baptized into one body, whether we be Jews or Gentiles, whether we be bond or free;
<br>and have been all made to drink into one Spirit.
<br></span></div><div style="position:absolute; border: textbox 1px solid; writing-mode:lr-tb; left:36px; top:78828px; width:270px; height:73px;"><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px">b.  </span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT-Bold; font-size:9px">Heb. 9:22,  25–26,  28. </span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px"> And almost all things are by the law purged with
<br>blood; and without shedding of  blood is no remission.… Nor yet that he should offer
<br>himself  often, as the high priest entereth into the holy place every year with blood of
<br>others; for then must he often have suffered since the foundation of  the world: but now
<br></span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px">once in the end of  the world hath he appeared to put away sin by the sacrifice of
<br></span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px">himself.… So Christ was once offered to bear the sins of  many; and unto them that
<br>look for him shall he appear the second time without sin unto salvation.  </span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT-Bold; font-size:9px">Heb. 10:10–
<br>14.</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px"> By the which will we are sanctified through the offering of  the body of  Jesus

<br></span></div><div style="position:absolute; border: textbox 1px solid; writing-mode:lr-tb; left:36px; top:80173px; width:269px; height:23px;"><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:11px">albeit, in substance and nature, they still remain truly and only bread
<br>and wine, as they were before.</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:8px">l
<br></span></div><div style="position:absolute; border: textbox 1px solid; writing-mode:lr-tb; left:36px; top:80196px; width:270px; height:80px;"><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:11px">6.  That doctrine which maintains a change of  the substance of
<br>bread and wine, into the substance of  Christ’s body and blood (com-
<br>monly called transubstantiation) by consecration of  a priest, or by
<br>any other way, is repugnant, not to Scripture alone, but even to com-
<br>mon sense, and reason; overthroweth the nature of  the sacrament,
<br>and hath been, and is, the cause of  manifold superstitions; yea, of
<br>gross idolatries.</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:8px">m
<br></span></div><div style="position:absolute; border: textbox 1px solid; writing-mode:lr-tb; left:36px; top:80277px; width:270px; height:92px;"><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:11px">7.  Worthy receivers, outwardly partaking of  the visible elements,
<br>in this sacrament,</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:8px">n</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:11px"> do then also, inwardly by faith, really and indeed,
<br>yet not carnally and corporally, but spiritually, receive, and feed upon,
<br>Christ crucified, and all benefits of  his death: the body and blood of
<br>Christ being then, not corporally or carnally, in, with, or under the
<br>bread and wine; yet, as really, but spiritually, present to the faith of
<br>believers in that ordinance, as the elements themselves are to their
<br>outward senses.</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:8px">o

<br>power of  our Lord Jesus Christ, to deliver such an one unto Satan for the destruction
<br>of  the flesh, that the spirit may be saved in the day of  the Lord Jesus. Your glorying is
<br>not good. Know ye not that a little leaven leaveneth the whole lump?… But now I
<br>have written unto you not to keep company, if  any man that is called a brother be a
<br></span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px">fornicator, or covetous, or an idolater, or a railer, or a drunkard, or an extortioner;
<br>with such an one no not to eat. For what have I to do to judge them also that are
<br>without? do not ye judge them that are within? But them that are without God judgeth.
<br>Therefore put away from among yourselves that wicked person.  </span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT-Bold; font-size:9px">1 Tim. 5:20.</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px"> Them
<br>that sin rebuke before all, that others also may fear.  </span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT-Bold; font-size:9px">Matt. 7:6.</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px"> Give not that which is

<br>that eateth and drinketh unworthily, eateth and drinketh damnation to himself, not

<br></span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px">And others save with fear, pulling them out of  the fire; hating even the garment spot-

<br></span></div><div style="position:absolute; border: textbox 1px solid; writing-mode:lr-tb; left:36px; top:82503px; width:270px; height:80px;"><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:11px">1.  For the better government, and further edification of  the church,

<br></span></div><div style="position:absolute; border: textbox 1px solid; writing-mode:lr-tb; left:49px; top:82583px; width:256px; height:11px;"><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:11px">2.  It belongeth to synods and councils, ministerially to determine
<br></span></div><div style="position:absolute; border: textbox 1px solid; writing-mode:lr-tb; left:35px; top:82602px; width:270px; height:55px;"><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px">Lord Jesus Christ, to deliver such an one unto Satan for the destruction of  the flesh,

<br></span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px">A man that is an heretick after the first and second admonition reject.

<br></span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px">of  them, should go up to Jerusalem unto the apostles and elders about this question.…

<br>apostles and elders, and they declared all things that God had done with them.… And
<br>the apostles and elders came together for to consider of  this matter.

<br>brethren, and said, Except ye be circumcised after the manner of  Moses, ye cannot be

<br>with them, they determined that Paul and Barnabas, and certain other of  them, should
<br>go up to Jerusalem unto the apostles and elders about this question.… But there rose
<br>up certain of  the sect of  the Pharisees which believed, saying, That it was needful to
<br>circumcise them, and to command them to keep the law of  Moses. And the apostles
<br>and elders came together for to consider of  this matter.… Then pleased it the apostles
<br>and  elders,  with  the  whole  church,  to  send  chosen  men  of   their  own  company  to
<br>Antioch with Paul and Barnabas; namely, Judas surnamed Barsabas, and Silas, chief
<br>men among the brethren: and they wrote letters by them after this manner; The apostles
<br>and elders and brethren send greeting unto the brethren which are of  the Gentiles in
<br>Antioch and Syria and Cilicia.… It seemed good unto us, being assembled with one
<br>accord, to send chosen men unto you with our beloved Barnabas and Paul.… For it
<br>seemed good to the Holy Ghost, and to us, to lay upon you no greater burden than
<br>these necessary things.… So when they were dismissed, they came to Antioch: and
<br></span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px">when they had gathered the multitude together, they delivered the epistle: which when
<br></span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px">they had read, they rejoiced for the consolation.…

See footnote </span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT-BoldItalic; font-size:9px">b</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT-Bold; font-size:9px"> above.</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px">  </span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT-Bold; font-size:9px">Acts 20:17.</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px"> And from Miletus he

<div style="position:absolute; border: textbox 1px solid; writing-mode:lr-tb; left:36px; top:83016px; width:12px; height:9px;"><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px">146

<br></span></div><div style="position:absolute; border: textbox 1px solid; writing-mode:lr-tb; left:257px; top:83016px; width:48px; height:9px;"><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px">CHAPTER 31
<br></span></div><div style="position:absolute; border: textbox 1px solid; writing-mode:lr-tb; left:36px; top:83033px; width:270px; height:92px;"><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:11px">controversies of  faith, and cases of  conscience; to set down rules and
<br>directions for the better ordering of  the public worship of  God, and
<br>government of  his church; to receive complaints in cases of  malad-
<br>ministration, and authoritatively to determine the same: which de-
<br>crees and determinations, if  consonant to the Word of  God, are to
<br>be received with reverence and submission; not only for their agree-
<br>ment with the Word, but also for the power whereby they are made,
<br>as being an ordinance of  God appointed thereunto in his Word.</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:8px">d

<br>eral or particular, may err; and many have erred. Therefore they are
<br>not to be made the rule of  faith, or practice; but to be used as a help
<br>in both.</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:8px">e

<br>that which is ecclesiastical: and are not to intermeddle with civil af-

<br></span></div><div style="position:absolute; border: textbox 1px solid; writing-mode:lr-tb; left:36px; top:83220px; width:270px; height:193px;"><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px">d.  </span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT-Bold; font-size:9px">Acts 15:15,  19,  24,  27–31.</span><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:9px"> And to this agree the words of  the prophets; as it

<br>agree on earth as touching any thing that they shall ask, it shall be done for them of

<br></span></div><div style="position:absolute; border: textbox 1px solid; writing-mode:lr-tb; left:68px; top:83675px; width:205px; height:13px;"><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT-Bold; font-size:13px">and of  the Resurrection of  the Dead
<br></span></div><div style="position:absolute; border: textbox 1px solid; writing-mode:lr-tb; left:35px; top:83700px; width:270px; height:69px;"><span style="font-family: BaskervilleMT; font-size:11px">1.    The  bodies  of   men,  after  death,  return  to  dust,  and  see
